Note: This is not the same as a pulse oximeter (SpO2%), although some models (such as this one) do measure both the oxygen and carbon monoxide saturation.]] [[File:Breath CO Monitor.jpg|thumb|Breath CO monitor displaying carbon monoxide concentration of an exhaled breath sample (in ppm) with its corresponding percent concentration of carboxyhemoglobin.]] As many symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning also occur with many other types of poisonings and infections (such as the flu), the diagnosis is often difficult.{{cite journal|vauthors=Bennetto L, Powter L, Scolding NJ |title=Accidental carbon monoxide poisoning presenting without a history of exposure: A case report|journal=Journal of Medical Case Reports|volume=2|issue=1|page=118|date=April 2008|pmid=18430228|doi=10.1186/1752-1947-2-118|pmc=2390579}} A history of potential carbon monoxide exposure, such as being exposed to a residential fire, may suggest poisoning, but the diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the levels of carbon monoxide in the blood. This can be determined by measuring the amount of [[carboxyhemoglobin]] compared to the amount of [[hemoglobin]] in the blood. The ratio of carboxyhemoglobin to hemoglobin molecules in an average person may be up to 5%, although cigarette smokers who smoke two packs per day may have levels up to 9%.{{cite book|veditors=Ford MD, Delaney KA, Ling LJ, Erickson T |title=Clinical Toxicology|year=2001|page=1046|publisher=WB Saunders Company|isbn=0721654851}} In symptomatic poisoned people they are often in the 10–30% range, while persons who die may have postmortem blood levels of 30–90%.Sato K, Tamaki K, Hattori H, et al. Determination of total hemoglobin in forensic blood samples with special reference to carboxyhemoglobin analysis. For. Sci. Int. 48: 89–96, 1990.R. Baselt, ''Disposition of Toxic Drugs and Chemicals in Man'', 8th edition, Biomedical Publications, Foster City, CA, 2008, pp. 237–41. As people may continue to experience significant symptoms of CO poisoning long after their blood carboxyhemoglobin concentration has returned to normal, presenting to examination with a normal carboxyhemoglobin level (which may happen in late states of poisoning) does not rule out poisoning.{{cite journal|vauthors=Keleş A, Demircan A, Kurtoğlu G |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: how many patients do we miss?|journal=European Journal of Emergency Medicine |volume=15|issue=3|pages=154–57|date=June 2008|pmid=18460956|doi=10.1097/MEJ.0b013e3282efd519}} ===Measuring=== Carbon monoxide may be quantitated in blood using [[spectrophotometry|spectrophotometric]] methods or [[chromatography|chromatographic techniques]] in order to confirm a diagnosis of poisoning in a person or to assist in the forensic investigation of a case of fatal exposure. A [[CO-oximeter]] can be used to determine carboxyhemoglobin levels.{{cite journal|vauthors=Rodkey FL, Hill TA, Pitts LL, Robertson RF |title=Spectrophotometric measurement of carboxyhemoglobin and methemoglobin in blood|journal=Clinical Chemistry|volume=25|issue=8|pages=1388–93|date=August 1979|pmid=455674|doi=|url=http://www.clinchem.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=455674|accessdate=2009-07-17}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Rees PJ, Chilvers C, Clark TJ |title=Evaluation of methods used to estimate inhaled dose of carbon monoxide|journal=Thorax|volume=35|issue=1|pages=47–51|date=January 1980|pmid=7361284|pmc=471219|doi= 10.1136/thx.35.1.47|url=http://thorax.bmj.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=7361284}} Pulse [[CO-oximeter]]s estimate carboxyhemoglobin with a non-invasive finger clip similar to a [[pulse oximeter]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Coulange M, Barthelemy A, Hug F, Thierry AL, De Haro L|title=Reliability of new pulse CO-oximeter in victims of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine|volume=35|issue=2|pages=107–11|date=March 2008|pmid=18500075|doi=|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/8084|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110625021038/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/8084|archivedate=2011-06-25|df=}} These devices function by passing various wavelengths of light through the fingertip and measuring the light absorption of the different types of hemoglobin in the capillaries.{{Cite journal|last = Maisel | first = William | authorlink = |author2=Roger J. Lewis | title = Noninvasive Measurement of Carboxyhemoglobin: How Accurate is Accurate Enough? | journal = Annals of Emergency Medicine | volume = 56 | issue = 4 | pages = 389–91 | publisher = | location = Boston, MA | year = 2010 | doi=10.1016/j.annemergmed.2010.05.025}} The use of a regular [[pulse oximeter]] is not effective in the diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning as people with carbon monoxide poisoning may have a normal [[oxygen saturation]] level on a pulse oximeter.{{cite journal|vauthors=Vegfors M, Lennmarken C |title=Carboxyhaemoglobinaemia and pulse oximetry|journal=British Journal of Anaesthesia|volume=66|issue=5|pages=625–626|date=May 1991|pmid=2031826|doi=10.1093/bja/66.5.625}} This is due to the carboxyhemoglobin being misrepresented as oxyhemoglobin.{{cite journal|vauthors=Barker SJ, Tremper KK |title=The effect of carbon monoxide inhalation on pulse oximetry and transcutaneous PO2|journal=Anesthesiology|volume=66|issue=5|pages=677–79|date=May 1987|pmid=3578881|doi=10.1097/00000542-198705000-00014}} [[Carbon monoxide breath monitor|Breath CO monitoring]] offers an alternative to pulse CO-oximetry. Carboxyhemoglobin levels have been shown to have a strong correlation with breath CO concentration.{{cite journal|first=M.|last=Jarvis|year=1986|title=Low cost carbon monoxide monitors in smoking assessment|journal=Thorax|pages=886–87|doi=10.1136/thx.41.11.886|volume=41|issue=11|pmc=460516}}{{cite journal|first=Nicholas|last=Wald|year=1981|title=Carbon monoxide in breath in relation to smoking and carboxyhaemoglobin levels|journal=Thorax|pages=366–69|doi=10.1136/thx.36.5.366|pmid=7314006|pmc=471511|volume=36|issue=5}} However, many of these devices require the user to inhale deeply and hold their breath to allow the CO in the blood to escape into the lung before the measurement can be made. As this is not possible in people who are unresponsive, these devices may not appropriate for use in on-scene emergency care detection of CO poisoning. === Differential diagnosis === There are many conditions to be considered in the differential diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning.{{cite journal |vauthors=Kao LW, Nañagas KA |title=Toxicity associated with carbon monoxide |journal=Clinics in Laboratory Medicine |volume=26 |issue=1 |pages=99–125 |date=March 2006 |pmid=16567227 |doi=10.1016/j.cll.2006.01.005}}{{cite web | last =Shochat | first =Guy N | title =Toxicity, Carbon Monoxide | publisher =[[emedicine]] | date =17 February 2009 | url =http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/819987-overview | accessdate =2009-04-27 | deadurl =no | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20090309072832/http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/819987-overview | archivedate =9 March 2009 | df = }} The earliest symptoms, especially from low level exposures, are often non-specific and readily confused with other illnesses, typically [[influenza|flu-like viral syndromes]], [[clinical depression|depression]], [[chronic fatigue syndrome]], [[chest pain]], and [[migraine]] or other headaches.{{cite journal | vauthors=Ilano AL, Raffin TA | title=Management of carbon monoxide poisoning | journal=Chest | date=Jan 1990 | pages=165–69 | volume=97 | issue=1 | pmid=2403894 | doi=10.1378/chest.97.1.165 }} Carbon monoxide has been called a "great mimicker" due to the presentation of poisoning being diverse and nonspecific. Other conditions included in the differential diagnosis include [[acute respiratory distress syndrome]], [[altitude sickness]], [[lactic acidosis]], [[diabetic ketoacidosis]], [[meningitis]], [[methemoglobinemia]], or [[Opioid overdose|opioid]] or toxic alcohol poisoning. == Prevention == [[File:CO DETECTOR (cropped).JPG|thumb|Carbon monoxide detector connected to a North American power outlet]] === Detectors === [[File:COMonitor.jpg|thumb|A carbon monoxide monitor clipped to the uniform of a paramedic]] Prevention remains a vital [[public health]] issue, requiring public education on the safe operation of appliances, heaters, fireplaces, and internal-combustion engines, as well as increased emphasis on the installation of [[carbon monoxide detector]]s.{{cite journal|vauthors=Ernst A, Zibrak JD |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=339|issue=22|pages=1603–08|date=November 1998|pmid=9828249|doi=10.1056/NEJM199811263392206|url=http://content.nejm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=short&pmid=9828249&promo=ONFLNS19}} Carbon monoxide is tasteless and odourless, and therefore can not be detected by visual cues or smell.{{cite journal |title=Compressed breathing air – the potential for evil from within |vauthors=Millar IL, Mouldey PG |year=2008 |volume=38 |issue=2 |pages=145–51 |journal=Diving and Hyperbaric Medicine |publisher=[[South Pacific Underwater Medicine Society]] |url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/7964 |accessdate=2013-04-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225063245/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/7964 |archivedate=2010-12-25 |df= |pmid=22692708 }} The United States [[Consumer Product Safety Commission]] has stated, "carbon monoxide detectors are as important to home safety as smoke detectors are," and recommends each home have at least one carbon monoxide detector, and preferably one on each level of the building. These devices, which are relatively inexpensive and widely available, are either battery- or AC-powered, with or without battery backup.{{cite web|last=Lipinski|first=Edward R|title=Keeping Watch on Carbon Monoxide|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 14, 1999|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/14/nyregion/home-clinic-keeping-watch-on-carbon-monoxide.html|accessdate=2009-09-09|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110623100533/http://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/14/nyregion/home-clinic-keeping-watch-on-carbon-monoxide.html|archivedate=June 23, 2011|df=}} In buildings, carbon monoxide detectors are usually installed around heaters and other equipment. If a relatively high level of carbon monoxide is detected, the device sounds an alarm, giving people the chance to evacuate and ventilate the building.{{cite journal |vauthors=Krenzelok EP, Roth R, Full R |title=Carbon monoxide ... the silent killer with an audible solution |journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine |date=September 1996 |pages=484–86 |volume=14 |issue=5 |pmid=8765117 |doi=10.1016/S0735-6757(96)90159-X }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Yoon SS, Macdonald SC, Parrish RG |title=Deaths from unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning and potential for prevention with carbon monoxide detectors |journal=JAMA |date=March 1998 |pages=685–87 |volume=279 |issue=9 |pmid=9496987 |doi=10.1001/jama.279.9.685 }} Unlike [[smoke detector]]s, carbon monoxide detectors do not need to be placed near ceiling level. The use of carbon monoxide detectors has been standardized in many areas. In the US, NFPA 720-2009,{{cite book|title=NFPA 720: Standard for the Installation of Carbon Monoxide (CO) Detection and Warning Equipment|publisher=National Fire Protection Agency|location=Quincy, MA|year=2009|pages=|isbn=}} the carbon monoxide detector guidelines published by the [[National Fire Protection Association]], mandates the placement of carbon monoxide detectors/alarms on every level of the residence, including the basement, in addition to outside sleeping areas. In new homes, AC-powered detectors must have battery backup and be interconnected to ensure early warning of occupants at all levels. NFPA 720-2009 is the first national carbon monoxide standard to address devices in non-residential buildings. These guidelines, which now pertain to schools, healthcare centers, nursing homes and other non-residential buildings, include three main points: :1. A secondary power supply (battery backup) must operate all carbon monoxide notification appliances for at least 12 hours, :2. Detectors must be on the ceiling in the same room as permanently installed fuel-burning appliances, and :3. Detectors must be located on every habitable level and in every [[HVAC]] zone of the building. Gas organizations will often recommend to get gas appliances serviced at least once a year.{{cite web|title=Gas Safety in the Home |publisher=UK Gas Safe Register |accessdate=2013-05-27 |url=http://www.gassaferegister.co.uk/advice/being_gas_safe.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502012946/http://gassaferegister.co.uk/advice/being_gas_safe.aspx |archivedate=2013-05-02 |df= }} === Legal requirements === The NFPA standard is not necessarily enforced by law. As of April 2006, the US state of Massachusetts requires detectors to be present in all residences with potential CO sources, regardless of building age and whether they are owner-occupied or rented.{{cite web|url=http://www.malegislature.gov/Laws/GeneralLaws/PartI/TitleXX/Chapter148/Section26F1~2|title=MGL Ch. 148 §28F{{frac|1|2}} – Nicole's Law, effective March 31, 2006|work=malegislature.gov|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121230154311/http://www.malegislature.gov/Laws/GeneralLaws/PartI/TitleXX/Chapter148/Section26F1~2|archivedate=December 30, 2012|df=}} This is enforced by municipal inspectors, and was inspired by the death of 7-year-old Nicole Garofalo in 2005 due to snow blocking a home heating vent.{{cite web |url=http://www.lawlib.state.ma.us/subject/about/carbonmonoxide.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130305145343/http://www.lawlib.state.ma.us/subject/about/carbonmonoxide.html |archivedate=2013-03-05 |df= }} Other jurisdictions may have no requirement or only mandate detectors for new construction or at time of sale. Despite similar deaths in vehicles with clogged exhaust pipes (for example in the [[Northeastern United States blizzard of 1978]] and [[February 2013 nor'easter]]) and the commercial availability of the equipment, there is no legal requirement for automotive CO detectors.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} ===World Health Organization recommendations=== The following guideline values (ppm values rounded) and periods of time-weighted average exposures have been determined in such a way that the carboxyhaemoglobin (COHb) level of 2.5% is not exceeded, even when a normal subject engages in light or moderate exercise: * 100 mg/m3 (87 ppm) for 15 min * 60 mg/m3 (52 ppm) for 30 min * 30 mg/m3 (26 ppm) for 1 h * 10 mg/m3 (9 ppm) for 8 h For indoor air quality 7 mg/m3 (6 ppm) for 24 h (so as not to exceed 2% COHb for chronic exposure) == Treatment == {| class="wikitable" style = "float: right; margin-left:15px; text-align:center;" |+ Time to remove 50% carboxy hemoglobin{{cite book|last1=Mathieu|first1=Daniel|title=Handbook on Hyperbaric Medicine|date=2006|publisher=Springer|location=[New York]|isbn=978-1402043765|edition=Online-Ausg.}} ! Oxygen pressure О2 ! Time |- |21% oxygen at normal atmospheric pressure (fresh air) | 5 hours 20 min |- |100% oxygen at normal atmospheric pressure (non-rebreather oxygen mask) | 1 hours 20 min |- |100% Hyperbaric oxygen (3 atmospheres absolute) | 23 min |} Initial treatment for carbon monoxide poisoning is to immediately remove the person from the exposure without endangering further people. Those who are unconscious may require [[Cardiopulmonary resuscitation|CPR]] on site. Administering [[oxygen]] via [[non-rebreather mask]] shortens the [[Biological half-life|half-life]] of carbon monoxide from 320 minutes, when breathing normal air, to only 80 minutes. Oxygen hastens the dissociation of carbon monoxide from [[carboxyhemoglobin]], thus turning it back into [[hemoglobin]].{{cite journal|author=Olson KR|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: Mechanisms, presentation, and controversies in management|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |volume=1|issue=3|pages=233–43|year=1984|pmid=6491241|doi=10.1016/0736-4679(84)90078-7}} Due to the possible severe effects in the fetus, pregnant women are treated with oxygen for longer periods of time than non-pregnant people.{{cite journal|author=Margulies JL|title=Acute carbon monoxide poisoning during pregnancy|journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine|volume=4|issue=6|pages=516–19|date=November 1986|pmid=3778597|doi=10.1016/S0735-6757(86)80008-0}} === Hyperbaric oxygen === [[File:HyperBaric Oxygen Therapy Chamber 2008.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|A person within a hyperbaric oxygen chamber]] [[Hyperbaric oxygen]] is also used in the treatment of carbon monoxide poisoning, as it may hasten dissociation of CO from carboxyhemoglobin and cytochrome oxidase{{cite journal|vauthors=Brown DB, Mueller GL, Golich FC |title=Hyperbaric oxygen treatment for carbon monoxide poisoning in pregnancy: a case report|journal=Aviation, Space, and Environmental Medicine|volume=63|issue=11|pages=1011–14|date=November 1992|pmid=1445151}} to a greater extent than normal oxygen. Hyperbaric oxygen at three times [[atmospheric pressure]] reduces the half life of carbon monoxide to 23 (~80/3 minutes) minutes, compared to 80 minutes for oxygen at regular atmospheric pressure. It may also enhance oxygen transport to the tissues by plasma, partially bypassing the normal transfer through hemoglobin. However, it is controversial whether hyperbaric oxygen actually offers any extra benefits over normal high flow oxygen, in terms of increased survival or improved long-term outcomes.{{Cite journal|last=Buckley|first=Nick A.|last2=Juurlink|first2=David N.|last3=Isbister|first3=Geoff|last4=Bennett|first4=Michael H.|last5=Lavonas|first5=Eric J.|date=2011-04-13|title=Hyperbaric oxygen for carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|issue=4|page=CD002041|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD002041.pub3|issn=1469-493X|pmid=21491385}}{{cite journal|author=Henry JA|title=Hyperbaric therapy for carbon monoxide poisoning: to treat or not to treat, that is the question|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|pages=149–150|year=2005|pmid=16390211|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00002}} {{cite journal|author=Olson KR|title=Hyperbaric oxygen or normobaric oxygen?|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|page=151; discussion 159–60|year=2005|pmid=16390212|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00003}}{{cite journal|author=Seger D|title=The myth|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|pages=155–56|year=2005|pmid=16390214|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00005}}{{cite journal|author=Thom SR|title=Hyperbaric oxygen therapy for carbon monoxide poisoning: Is it time to end the debates?|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|pages=157–58|year=2005|pmid=16390215|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00006}} There have been [[randomized controlled trial]]s in which the two treatment options have been compared;{{cite journal|vauthors=Scheinkestel CD, Bailey M, Myles PS, Jones K, Cooper DJ, Millar IL, Tuxen DV|title=Hyperbaric or normobaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning: a randomized controlled clinical trial|journal=[[The Medical Journal of Australia]]|date=March 1999|pages=203–10|volume=170|issue=5|pmid=10092916|url=http://www.mja.com.au/public/issues/mar1/scheink/scheink.html|format=Free full text|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905012917/https://www.mja.com.au/public/issues/mar1/scheink/scheink.html|archivedate=2008-09-05|df=}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Thom SR, Taber RL, Mendiguren II, Clark JM, Hardy KR, Fisher AB |title=Delayed neuropsychologic sequelae after carbon monoxide poisoning: prevention by treatment with hyperbaric oxygen|journal=Annals of Emergency Medicine|date=April 1995|pages=474–80|volume=25|issue=4|pmid=7710151|doi=10.1016/S0196-0644(95)70261-X}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Raphael JC, Elkharrat D, Jars-Guincestre MC, Chastang C, Chasles V, Vercken JB, Gajdos P |title=Trial of normobaric and hyperbaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide intoxication|journal=Lancet|date=August 1989|pages=414–19|volume=2|issue=8660|pmid=2569600|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(89)90592-8}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Ducasse JL, Celsis P, Marc-Vergnes JP|title=Non-comatose patients with acute carbon monoxide poisoning: hyperbaric or normobaric oxygenation?|journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine|date=March 1995|pages=9–15|volume=22|issue=1|pmid=7742714|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/2193|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811174818/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/2193|archivedate=2011-08-11|df=}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Mathieu D, Mathieu-Nolf M, Durak C, Wattel F, Tempe JP, Bouachour G, Sainty JM|title=Randomized prospective study comparing the effect of HBO vs 12 hours NBO in non-comatose CO-poisoned patients: results of the preliminary analysis|journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine|year=1996|page=7|volume=23|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/447|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110702235523/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/447|archivedate=2011-07-02|df=}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Weaver LK, Hopkins RO, Chan KJ, Churchill S, Elliott CG, Clemmer TP, Orme JF, Thomas FO, Morris AH |title=Hyperbaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|date=October 2002|pages=1057–67|volume=347|issue=14|pmid=12362006|doi=10.1056/NEJMoa013121}} of the six performed, four found hyperbaric oxygen improved outcome and two found no benefit for hyperbaric oxygen.{{cite journal|vauthors=Buckley NA, Isbister GK, Stokes B, Juurlink DN |title=Hyperbaric oxygen for carbon monoxide poisoning: a systematic review and critical analysis of the evidence|journal=Toxicological Reviews|year=2005|pages=75–92|volume=24|issue=2|pmid=16180928|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524020-00002}} Some of these trials have been criticized for apparent flaws in their implementation.{{cite journal|author=Gorman DF.|title=Hyperbaric or normobaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning: a randomised controlled clinical trial. Unfortunate methodological flaws|journal=The Medical Journal of Australia|date=June 1999|pages=563; author reply 564–65|volume=170|issue=11|pmid=10397050}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Scheinkestel CD, Jones K, Myles PS, Cooper DJ, Millar IL, Tuxen DV |title=Where to now with carbon monoxide poisoning?|journal=Emergency Medicine Australasia: EMA|date=April 2004|pages=151–54|volume=16|issue=2|pmid=15239731|doi=10.1111/j.1742-6723.2004.00567.x}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Isbister GK, McGettigan P, Harris I |title=Hyperbaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|date=February 2003|pages=557–60|volume=348|issue=6|pmid=12572577|doi=10.1056/NEJM200302063480615}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Buckley NA, Juurlink DN |title=Carbon monoxide treatment guidelines must acknowledge the limitations of the existing evidence |journal=American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine |volume=187 |issue=12 |page=1390 |date=June 2013 |pmid=23767905 |doi=10.1164/rccm.201212-2262LE}} A review of all the literature concluded that the role of hyperbaric oxygen is unclear and the available evidence neither confirms nor denies a medically meaningful benefit. The authors suggested a large, well designed, externally audited, multicentre trial to compare normal oxygen with hyperbaric oxygen. === Other === Further treatment for other complications such as [[seizure]], hypotension, cardiac abnormalities, [[pulmonary edema]], and [[acidosis]] may be required. Increased muscle activity and seizures should be treated with [[dantrolene]] or [[diazepam]]; diazepam should only be given with appropriate respiratory support. Hypotension requires treatment with intravenous fluids; [[vasopressor]]s may be required to treat myocardial depression.{{cite journal|author=Tomaszewski C|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning. Early awareness and intervention can save lives|journal=Postgraduate Medicine|volume=105|issue=1|pages=39–40, 43–48, 50|date=January 1999|pmid=9924492|doi=10.3810/pgm.1999.01.496}} [[Cardiac dysrhythmia]]s are treated with standard [[advanced cardiac life support]] protocols. If severe, metabolic acidosis is treated with [[sodium bicarbonate]]. Treatment with sodium bicarbonate is controversial as acidosis may increase tissue oxygen availability.{{cite journal|author=Peirce EC|title=Treating acidemia in carbon monoxide poisoning may be dangerous|journal=Journal of Hyperbaric Medicine|volume=1|issue=2|pages=87–97|year=1986|pmid=|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/4304|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110703000244/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/4304|archivedate=2011-07-03|df=}} Treatment of acidosis may only need to consist of oxygen therapy. The delayed development of neuropsychiatric impairment is one of the most serious complications of carbon monoxide poisoning. Brain damage is confirmed following [[magnetic resonance imaging|MRI]] or [[X-ray computed tomography|CAT]] scans.{{cite journal|vauthors=Devine SA, Kirkley SM, Palumbo CL, White RF |title=MRI and neuropsychological correlates of carbon monoxide exposure: a case report |journal=Environmental Health Perspectives |volume=110 |issue=10 |pages=1051–55 |date=October 2002 |pmid=12361932 |pmc=1241033 |doi=10.1289/ehp.021101051 |url=http://ehpnet1.niehs.nih.gov/members/2002/110p1051-1055devine/devine-full.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120707154535/http://ehpnet1.niehs.nih.gov/members/2002/110p1051-1055devine/devine-full.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-07 }}{{cite journal|vauthors=O'Donnell P, Buxton PJ, Pitkin A, Jarvis LJ |title=The magnetic resonance imaging appearances of the brain in acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Clinical Radiology|volume=55|issue=4|pages=273–80|date=April 2000|pmid=10767186|doi=10.1053/crad.1999.0369}} Extensive follow up and supportive treatment is often required for delayed neurological damage. Outcomes are often difficult to predict following poisoning,{{cite journal|vauthors=Seger D, Welch L |title=Carbon monoxide controversies: neuropsychologic testing, mechanism of toxicity, and hyperbaric oxygen|journal=Annals of Emergency Medicine|volume=24|issue=2|pages=242–48|date=August 1994|pmid=8037390|doi=10.1016/S0196-0644(94)70136-9}} especially people who have symptoms of [[cardiac arrest]], [[coma]], [[metabolic acidosis]], or have high carboxyhemoglobin levels. One study reported that approximately 30% of people with severe carbon monoxide poisoning will have a fatal outcome. It has been reported that electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) may increase the likelihood of delayed neuropsychiatric sequelae (DNS) after carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning.{{cite journal|last=Chiang|first=CL|author2=Tseng, MC|title=Safe use of electroconvulsive therapy in a highly suicidal survivor of carbon monoxide poisoning.|journal=Gen Hosp Psychiatry|date=27 September 2011}} == Epidemiology == {{Category see also|Deaths from carbon monoxide poisoning}} The true number of cases of carbon monoxide poisoning is unknown, since many non-lethal exposures go undetected. From the available data, carbon monoxide poisoning is the most common cause of injury and death due to poisoning worldwide.{{cite journal|author=Thom SR|title=Hyperbaric-oxygen therapy for acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=347|issue=14|pages=1105–06|date=October 2002|pmid=12362013|doi=10.1056/NEJMe020103}} Poisoning is typically more common during the winter months.{{cite journal |vauthors=Ernst A, Zibrak JD |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=The New England Journal of Medicine |volume=339 |issue=22 |pages=1603–08 |date=November 1998 |pmid=9828249 |doi=10.1056/NEJM199811263392206}}{{cite journal |author=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) |title=Deaths from motor-vehicle-related unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning—Colorado, 1996, New Mexico, 1980–1995, and United States, 1979–1992 |journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report |volume=45 |issue=47 |pages=1029–32 |date=November 1996 |pmid=8965803 |doi= |url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwR/preview/mmwrhtml/00044617.htm |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170624012603/https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00044617.htm |archivedate=2017-06-24 |df= }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Partrick M, Fiesseler F, Shih R, Riggs R, Hung O |title=Monthly variations in the diagnosis of carbon monoxide exposures in the emergency department |journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine |volume=36 |issue=3 |pages=161–67 |year=2009 |pmid=19860138}} This is due to increased domestic use of gas furnaces, gas or kerosene [[space heater]]s, and kitchen stoves during the winter months, which if faulty and/or used without adequate ventilation, may produce excessive carbon monoxide.{{cite journal |author=Heckerling PS |title=Occult carbon monoxide poisoning: a cause of winter headache |journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine |volume=5 |issue=3 |pages=201–04 |date=May 1987 |pmid=3580051 |doi= 10.1016/0735-6757(87)90320-2|url=}} Carbon monoxide detection and poisoning also increases during power outages, when electric heating and cooking appliances become inoperative and residents may temporarily resort to fuel-burning space heaters, stoves, and grills (some of which are safe only for outdoor use but nonetheless are errantly burned indoors).{{cite web|title=Department of Public Health Warns of Dangers of Carbon Monoxide Poisoning During Power Outages|url=http://www.towergenerator.com/Resources/Power_Generator_Carbon_Monoxide_Dangers/|publisher=Tower Generator|accessdate=2011-11-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426001248/http://www.towergenerator.com/Resources/Power_Generator_Carbon_Monoxide_Dangers/|archivedate=2012-04-26|df=}}{{cite web|title=Avoiding Carbon Monoxide poisoning during a power outage |url=http://www.bt.cdc.gov/disasters/psa/co.asp |publisher=CDC |accessdate=2011-11-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111212171534/http://www.bt.cdc.gov/disasters/psa/co.asp |archivedate=2011-12-12 |df= }}{{cite journal|last=Klein|first=Kelly|author2=Herzog, Perri |author3=Smolinske, Susan |author4= White, Suzanne |title=Demand for poison control center services "surged" during the 2003 blackout.|journal=Clinical Toxicology|year=2007|volume=45|issue=3|pages=248–54|doi=10.1080/15563650601031676 |pmid=17453875}} It has been estimated that more than 40,000 people per year seek medical attention for carbon monoxide poisoning in the United States.{{cite journal|author=Hampson NB|title=Emergency department visits for carbon monoxide poisoning in the Pacific Northwest|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |date=September 1998|pages=695–98|volume=16|issue=5|pmid=9752939|doi=10.1016/S0736-4679(98)00080-8}} 95% of carbon monoxide poisoning deaths in the United States are due to gas space heaters.{{cite web|url=http://www.esv.vic.gov.au/Portals/0/About%20ESV/Files/Gas%20use%20reports/2004AddendumtoOverseasandAustralianStatisticsandBenchmarksforCustomerGasSafetyIncidents.pdf|title=2004 Addendum to Overseas and Australian Statistics and Benchmarks for Customer Gas Safety Incidents|publisher=Office of Gas Safety, Victoria|year=2004|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924002528/http://www.esv.vic.gov.au/Portals/0/About%20ESV/Files/Gas%20use%20reports/2004AddendumtoOverseasandAustralianStatisticsandBenchmarksforCustomerGasSafetyIncidents.pdf|archivedate=2015-09-24|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.scer.gov.au/files/2012/03/EMR2-QRA-Final.pdf |title=The risk of carbon monoxide poisoning from domestic gas appliances |work=Report to the Department of Resources, Energy and Tourism |date=Feb 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150312065135/http://www.scer.gov.au/files/2012/03/EMR2-QRA-Final.pdf |archivedate=2015-03-12 |df= }} In many industrialized countries carbon monoxide is the cause of more than 50% of fatal poisonings. In the United States, approximately 200 people die each year from carbon monoxide poisoning associated with home fuel-burning heating equipment.{{cite web|title=Carbon Monoxide Detectors Can Save Lives: CPSC Document #5010|publisher=US Consumer Product Safety Commission|url=http://www.cpsc.gov/CPSCPUB/PUBS/5010.html|accessdate=2009-04-30|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090409030219/http://www.cpsc.gov/CPSCPUB/PUBS/5010.html |archivedate=2009-04-09}} Carbon monoxide poisoning contributes to the approximately 5613 smoke inhalation deaths each year in the United States.{{cite journal|vauthors=Cobb N, Etzel RA|title=Unintentional carbon monoxide-related deaths in the United States, 1979 through 1988|journal=JAMA|volume=266|issue=5|pages=659–63|date=August 7, 1991|pmid=1712865|url=http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/266/5/659|doi=10.1001/jama.266.5.659|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080921102448/http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/266/5/659|archivedate=September 21, 2008|df=}} The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] reports, "Each year, more than 500 Americans die from unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning, and more than 2,000 commit suicide by intentionally poisoning themselves."{{cite web|title=Carbon Monoxide poisoning fact sheet|publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|date=July 2006|url=https://www.cdc.gov/co/pdfs/faqs.pdf|format=pdf|doi=|accessdate=2008-12-16|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218085439/http://www.cdc.gov/co/pdfs/faqs.pdf|archivedate=2008-12-18|df=}} For the 10-year period from 1979 to 1988, 56,133 deaths from carbon monoxide poisoning occurred in the United States, with 25,889 of those being suicides, leaving 30,244 unintentional deaths. A report from [[New Zealand]] showed that 206 people died from carbon monoxide poisoning in the years of 2001 and 2002. In total carbon monoxide poisoning was responsible for 43.9% of deaths by poisoning in that country.{{cite journal|vauthors=McDowell R, Fowles J, Phillips D|title=Deaths from poisoning in New Zealand: 2001–2002|journal=[[The New Zealand Medical Journal]]|volume=118|issue=1225|page=U1725|date=November 2005|pmid=16286939|url=http://www.nzmj.com/journal/118-1225/1725/|format=Free full text|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110714220921/http://www.nzmj.com/journal/118-1225/1725/|archivedate=2011-07-14|df=}} In [[South Korea]], 1,950 people had been poisoned by carbon monoxide with 254 deaths from 2001 through 2003.{{cite journal|vauthors=Song KJ, Shin SD, Cone DC |title=Socioeconomic status and severity-based incidence of poisoning: a nationwide cohort study|journal=[[Clinical Toxicology]]|volume=47|issue=8|pages=818–26|date=September 2009|pmid=19640232|doi=10.1080/15563650903158870}} A report from [[Jerusalem]] showed 3.53 per 100,000 people were poisoned annually from 2001 through 2006.{{cite journal|vauthors=Salameh S, Amitai Y, Antopolsky M, Rott D, Stalnicowicz R |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning in Jerusalem: epidemiology and risk factors|journal=Clinical Toxicology|volume=47|issue=2|pages=137–41|date=February 2009|pmid=18720104|doi=10.1080/15563650801986711}} In [[Hubei]], China, 218 deaths from poisoning were reported over a 10-year period with 16.5% being from carbon monoxide exposure.{{cite journal |vauthors=Liu Q, Zhou L, Zheng N, Zhuo L, Liu Y, Liu L |title=Poisoning deaths in China: type and prevalence detected at the Tongji Forensic Medical Center in Hubei |journal=Forensic Science International |volume=193 |issue=1–3 |pages=88–94 |date=December 2009 |pmid=19854011 |doi=10.1016/j.forsciint.2009.09.013}} ==History== The earliest description of carbon monoxide poisoning dates to at least 200 BC by [[Aristotle]]. Documented cases of carbon monoxide being used as a [[Suicide methods#Carbon monoxide|method of suicide]] date to at least 100 BC in [[ancient Rome]].{{cite book|last1=Penney|first1=David G.|title=Carbon Monoxide Poisoning|date=2007|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0849384189|page=754|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=793KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA754|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910172025/https://books.google.com/books?id=793KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA754|archivedate=2017-09-10|df=}} In the AD 350s, the Roman emperor [[Julian (emperor)|Julian]] suffered from carbon monoxide poisoning in Paris, and later described it in his work ''Misopogon'': "though the winter weather prevailed and continually increased in severity, even so I did not allow my servants to heat the house, because I was afraid of drawing out the dampness in the walls; but I ordered them to carry in fire that had burned down and to place in the room a very moderate number of hot coals. But the coals, though there were not very many of them, brought out from the walls quantities of steam and this made me fall asleep. And since my head was filled with the fumes I was almost choked. Then I was carried outside."Julian, ''Misopogon'' 341C-D This misunderstanding of the causes of carbon monoxide poisoning may have caused the death of Julian's successor, [[Jovian (emperor)|Jovian]]. [[John Scott Haldane]] identified carbon monoxide as the lethal constituent of [[afterdamp]], the gas created by [[combustion]], after examining many bodies of miners killed in pit explosions. Their skin was coloured cherry-pink from [[carboxyhaemoglobin]], the stable compound formed in the blood by reaction with the gas. As a result of his research, he was able to design respirators for rescue workers. He tested the effect of carbon monoxide on his own body in a closed chamber, describing the results of his slow poisoning. In the late 1890s, he introduced the use of small animals for miners to detect dangerous levels of carbon monoxide underground, either white mice or canaries. With a faster metabolism, they showed the effects of poisoning before gas levels became critical for the workers, and so gave an early warning of the problem. The [[canary in a coal mine|canary]] in British pits was replaced in 1986 by the electronic gas detector. As part of the [[Holocaust]] during [[World War II]], German [[Nazi]]s used [[gas van]]s at [[Chelmno extermination camp]] and elsewhere to kill an estimated over 700,000 prisoners by carbon monoxide poisoning. This method was also used in the gas chambers of several [[extermination camp|death camps]] such as [[Treblinka]], [[Sobibor]] and [[Belzec]]. Gassing with carbon monoxide started in [[action T4]], the programme developed by the Nazis in Germany to murder the mentally ill and [[disabled people]] before the war started in earnest. The gas was supplied by [[IG Farben]] in pressurized cylinders and fed by tubes into the gas chambers built at various mental hospitals, such as [[Hartheim Euthanasia Centre]]. Many key personnel were recruited from the T4 programme to murder much larger numbers of people in the gas vans and the special [[gas chamber]]s used in the [[death camp]]s such as [[Treblinka]]. [[Exhaust fumes]] from tank engines for example, were used to supply the gas to the chambers.{{cite book|title=Dictionary of Genocide|vauthors=Totten S, Bartrop P, Markusen E|year=2007|publisher=Greenwood|pages=129, 156|url=https://books.google.com/?id=rgGA91skoP4C&lpg=PA156&dq=nazi%20carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&pg=PA156#v=onepage&q=carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&f=false|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130526000146/http://books.google.com/books?id=rgGA91skoP4C&lpg=PA156&ots=S8jhBY6NxB&dq=nazi%20carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&pg=PA156#v=onepage&q=carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&f=false|archivedate=2013-05-26|df=|isbn=978-0313346422}} The use of oxygen as treatment began in 1868. The use of hyperbaric oxygen in rats following poisoning was studied by Haldane in 1895 while its use in humans began in the 1960s. ==Research== Carbon monoxide is produced naturally by the body as a byproduct of converting [[protoporphyrin]] into [[bilirubin]]. This carbon monoxide also combines with hemoglobin to make carboxyhemoglobin, but not at toxic levels. Small amounts of CO are beneficial and enzymes exist that produce it at times of oxidative stress. Drugs are being developed to introduce small amounts of CO during certain kinds of surgery, these drugs are called [[carbon monoxide-releasing molecules]].{{cite journal|last1=Foresti|first1=R|last2=Bani-Hani|first2=MG|last3=Motterlini|first3=R|title=Use of carbon monoxide as a therapeutic agent: promises and challenges.|journal=Intensive Care Medicine|date=April 2008|volume=34|issue=4|pages=649–58|pmid=18286265|doi=10.1007/s00134-008-1011-1}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Medical resources | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = {{ICD10|T|58}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|986}} | eMedicineSubj = article | eMedicineTopic = 819987 | MeshID = D002249 }} * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/co-comp/ Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) – Carbon Monoxide – NIOSH Workplace Safety and Health Topic] * International Programme on Chemical Safety (1999). [http://www.who.int/ipcs/publications/ehc/ehc_213/en/ Carbon Monoxide], Environmental Health Criteria 213, Geneva: WHO {{Poisoning and toxicity}} {{good article}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Carbon Monoxide Poisoning}} [[Category:Carbon monoxide|Poisoning]] [[Category:Accidents]] [[Category:Industrial hygiene]] [[Category:Medical emergencies]] [[Category:Natural gas safety]] [[Category:Suicide methods]] [[Category:Toxic effects of substances chiefly nonmedicinal as to source]] [[Category:RTT]] [[Category:RTTEM]]

{{citation style|date=December 2016|details=the sources of citations need to be explicitly specified}}
'''Devendrar Jayanthi''' is a festival celebrated annually on 11 September. It is organised by various political parties, community organisations and civil societies in Southern Tamil Nadu to commemorate the memory of [[Immanuvel Devendrar]], a freedom fighter and [[Indian National Congress]] leader who took part in the [[Quit India Movement|Quit India movement]] during the [[British Raj]] era.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewsminute.com/article/remembering-immanuel-sekaran-brave-dalit-leader-who-lost-his-life-savarna-brutality-49168|title=Thiyagi Immanuel Sekaran}}</ref> He worked in the [[Indian Army]] in independent India and later he fought for the rights of depressed class people of Southern Tamil Nadu, particularly for upliftment of [[Pallar]] caste.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/freedom-fighter-dalit-icon-remembering-tamil-nadu-s-immanuel-sekaran/story-EzBsVdnsQj9gQzuuNKdDiI.html|title=Immanuel Sekaran an Icon of depressed class}}</ref> He was a close associate of chief minister [[K. Kamaraj]].
==Political background== [[File:Devendrar_Jayanthi_in_Paramakudi.jpg|thumb|200px|Gathering at Immanuel sekaran memorial on Devendrar jayanthi]]
Immanuel Devendrar was a member of the Indian National Congress and a close associate of its leader, K. Kamaraj. At that time, Congress was supported by influential communities of southern Tamil Nadu, such as the Pallars and [[Nadar (caste)|Nadars]], and opposed by the [[Forward Block]], which was itself favoured by the [[Maravar]] community. The two sides clashed during elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-tamilnadu/immanuel-sekaran-in-the-vanguard-of-dalit-struggle/article2443838.ece|title=Caste riots of South Tamilnadu}}</ref> Violence erupted notably in the districts of [[Ramanathapuram district|Ramanathapuram]] and [[Madurai district|Madurai]] which claimed over 40 lives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.frontline.in/static/html/fl1522/15220360.htm|title=Series of violence that shooked the south}}</ref> Devendrar was killed at this time and the anniversary of his death is today celebrated by various political parties and community organisations and civil societies as Devendrar Jayanthi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/freedom-fighter-dalit-icon-remembering-tamil-nadu-s-immanuel-sekaran/story-EzBsVdnsQj9gQzuuNKdDiI.html|title=Devendrar jayanthi}}</ref>
==Criticism== Devendrar Jayanti is among the celebrations sometimes criticised as being designed mainly as expressions of caste pride and political power, which sometimes turn into inter-caste violence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/chennai/Two-month-ban-issued-in-Ramanathapuram-district/articleshow/42094253.cms|title=Law and Order problem}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.frontline.in/static/html/fl2820/stories/20111007282012800.htm|title=Paramakudi police firing}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uniindia.com/dalit-leader-immanuel-death-anniversary-passes-off-peacefully/other/news/620462.html|title=Immanuel devendrar remebrance day passes of peacefully}}</ref> The critics claim that political parties used them as a form of [[vote bank]] politics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://swarajyamag.com/politics/tamil-nadu-caste-realities-unlikely-to-change-any-time-soon|title=Caste reality of Tamilnadu politics}}</ref>
These critics are rebutted by people who say that every caste has its own leader and the people are celebrating the memories of their leaders. Despite of these arguments every year the government is struggling to maintain the law and order during these celebrations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vikatan.com/news/tamilnadu/10365.art|title=Immanueal Sekaran jayanthi celebrations}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.dailyhunt.in/news/india/english/hindustan+times-epaper-httimes/freedom+fighter+dalit+icon+remembering+tamil+nadu+s+immanuel+sekaran-newsid-57791528|title=Sekaran jayanthi passes of peacefully}}</ref>

{{advert|date=February 2013}} {{use mdy dates|date=May 2013}} '''The Digitas NewFront''' is an annual [[marketing]] [[Business conference|conference]] first held during [[Internet Week New York]]. Hosted by [[Digitas]] and its brand content entity, The Third Act, the event's stated purpose is to "bring together content creators, distributors, talent and brands to harness creative media opportunities made possible in the age of digital marketing". In 2009, it was broadcast via public webcast.<ref>[http://www.thenewfront.com The NewFronts 2009]. thenewfront.com.</ref> The event was produced by Amanda Anderson.
==History== <!-- what about pre-2008 "Digital Content NewFront" history? Come on. Wikipedia articles are not intended to be proprietary. Discuss in Talk --> First launched in 2008, the event was titled "Digital Content NewFront". The event title was later shortened to "The NewFront" with the stated mission to "explore and help evolve the brand content and distribution landscape". The event showcased online video content companies like 60 Frames, [[MySpaceTV]], [[MTV New Media]], Generate, [[Next New Networks]] and [[Vuguru]]. Speakers and panelists included [[Michael Eisner]], CEO of Tornate and Vuguru, former Disney CEO and [[Dmitry Shapiro]], the founder of [[Veoh]] Networks.<ref>McCarthy, Caroline (June 5, 2009). [http://news.cnet.com/8301-13577_3-9960970-36.html?tag=blog.1 "Who’s afraid of online video? Not Michael Eisner"]. CNET.</ref>
In 2018, the NewFronts ran for one week rather than two.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Shorter NewFronts Highlight Bigger Content Players|last=Lafayette|first=Jon|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=April 30, 2018|pages=10-13}}</ref>
===Notable speakers and participants ===
====2009 ==== * [[Al Gore]], former Vice President and co-founder of [[Current TV]].<ref>McCarthy, Caroline (June 3, 2009). [http://news.cnet.com/8301-13577_3-10256230-36.html "Al Gore wants to save advertising, too"], CNET.</ref> * [[Tom Green]], actor and comedian, led a live version of his digital talk show, ''[[Tom Green's House Tonight|Tom Green Live]]''. Guests included: [[Craig Brewer]], director, [http://www.mtv.com/fivedollarcover/ $5 Cover]; [[Paula Deen]], Paula Deen Enterprises and star of ''Get Cookin' with Paula Deen''; [[Milo Ventimiglia]], actor, producer and founder of [[Divide Pictures]]; [[Faith Ford]], actress and host of MSN's original web series, ''Mind Body Balance''; and [[Kevin Nalty]], blogger and YouTube star. * [[Daisy Whitney]], multimedia reporter (ABCNews.com and KNTV) and host of her own show ''New Media Minute'', led a panel on measuring brand content programs <ref>[http://www.digitalcontentnewfront.com "The NewFronts 2009"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090225192346/http://www.digitalcontentnewfront.com/ |date=February 25, 2009 }}. digitalcontentnewfront.com.</ref>
====2010 ==== * [[Kevin Pollak]], actor and host of ''[[Kevin Pollak's Chat Show]]'' led a live version of his popular digital talk show. Guests included: [[Lisa Kudrow]], the star of ''[[Web Therapy]]''; [[Teri Hatcher]], co-creator of [http://www.gethatched.com/ ''GetHatched.com'']; [[Ben Silverment|Ben Silverman]], founder and CEO of Electus; and [[Ricky Van Veen]], founder of [[CollegeHumor]] and Notional.<ref>[http://www.pitchengine.com/digitalcontentnewfront/digitas-and-the-third-act-present-digital-content-newfront-2010/65279/ "Digitas and The Third Act: Present Digital Content NewFront 2010"]. pitchengine.com.<!-- supporting whole section --></ref>
====2011 participants==== *An opening keynote with [[Philip J. Crowley]],<ref>[http://www.clickz.com/clickz/column/2078237/social-media "What Not to Do on Social Media"]. clickz.com.</ref> former assistant secretary for public affairs at the State Department and Amr Salama, an Egyptian filmmaker and blogger.<ref>[http://www.petitweb.fr/actualites/egypte-le-social-media-nous-a-rendu-notre-dignite/ "Egypte : le social média nous a rendu notre dignité"] (in French), Petit Web, June 14, 2011.</ref> *Live content pitches from [[Isabella Rossellini]],<ref>[http://news.tubefilter.tv/2011/06/09/isabella-rossellini-goes-from-porno-to-parenting/ "Isabella Rossellini Goes From Porno to Parenting"]. Tubefilter.com.</ref> [[Demi Moore]],<ref>Oldenburg, Ann (June 20, 2011). [http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2011/06/demi-does-new-york-mtv-cancels-skins/1 "Demi Does New York; Kanye West and Mary-Kate Olsen?"], ''USA Today'', June 10, 2011</ref> [[Amanda de Cadenet]], [[Tyra Banks]],<ref>Griffith, Erin (June 9, 2011). [http://www.adweek.com/internet-week-blog/teatime-tyra-132400 "Tea Time With Tyra"], ''AdWeek''.</ref> [[Zachary Quinto]], Neal Dodson, [[Soleil Moon Frye]],<ref>[http://bostinnovation.com/2011/05/18/brands-meet-content-digitas-kraft-dive-in-with-hersay/ "Digitas, Kraft Dive in with Hersay"] Bostinnovation.com.</ref><ref>[http://www.life.com/image/115748806 "Life Images"]. Life Magazine online.{{failed verification|date=May 2013}}<!-- also title is not specific enough to help find a replacement source--></ref> and more. *A talk with [[Ashton Kutcher]]<ref>[http://scene.yahoo.net/iwny-2011/the-sessions/sessions/ashton-kutcher-urges-marketers-to-disrupt "Ashton Kutcher Urges Marketers to Disrupt"]. Scene.yahoo.com.</ref> about his digital entertainment company, [[Katalyst Media]]. *A panel discussion on brands as publishers with executives Beth Comstock ([[General Electric]]), Susan Popper ([[SAP AG|SAP]]), Susan Sobbott ([[American Express]] OPEN),<ref>[http://www.petitweb.fr/actualites/oublier-le-juridique-pour-entrer-dans-la-conversation/ "Oublier le juridique pour entrer dans la conversation"] (in French), Petit Web, June 14, 2011.</ref> [[Steven Rosenbaum]], author of Curation Nation,<ref>Griffith, Erin (June 9, 2011). [http://www.adweek.com/internet-week-blog/brands-love-content-when-they-make-it-132405/ "Brands Love Content When They Make It"], ''AdWeek''.</ref> and [[John Battelle]], as the moderator.<ref>[http://scene.yahoo.net/iwny-2011/the-sessions/sessions/story-telling-the-new-way-to-market "Story-Telling: The New Way to Market"]. Scene.yahoo.com.</ref> *A panel discussion with [[Robert Kyncl]] ([[Google]]), Rio Caraeff ([[Vevo]]), [[?uestlove]], and Rich Lehrfeld ([[American Express]]) discussed the shifting of strategies to scale to larger engaging experiences for fans.<ref>[http://www.onlinevideo.net/2011/06/exploring-the-new-front-between-entertainment-and-advertising/ "Exploring the New Front Between Entertainment and Advertising"]. Onlinevideo.net. June 2011.</ref> *A round table discussion on how today's "modern family" consumes media with [[Kevin Jonas]], 12-year-old singer/actress [[Jenna Rose]], 11-year-old chef Lizzie Marie and actors [[Tori Spelling]] and [[Dean McDermott]], moderated by [[Jane Pratt]].<ref>[http://blog.saymedia.com/2011/06/today-at-the-newfront-2011-hosted-by-digitasxojanecoms-editor-in-chief-and-says-editorial-director-style-jane-pratt-wil.html "Jane Pratt Hosts ''Modern Family'' Panel with Tori Spelling and Kevin Jonas"]. Saymedia.com. June 2011.</ref>
====2012 ==== *Emcees: [[JB Smoove]] & [[Ali Wentworth]] *[[Andrew Ross Sorkin]], Author of Too Big To Fail *A panel discussion about digital authenticity with stars of the social screen led by [[Piers Morgan]] with [[Kristin Chenoweth]], [[Felicia Day]] and [[Michelle Phan]]<ref>[http://michellephan.com/my-week-in-photos-6/ "My Week in Photos: Michelle Phan] MichellePhan.com. April 2012.</ref> *A discussion with Chief Marketing Officers led by [[Adam Ostrow]], Chief Strategy Officer for [[Mashable]], with Christa Carone (CMO, [[Xerox]]), [[Michael Lazerow]] (Founder, Chairman, CEO, Buddy Media) and [[Diego Scotti]] (CMO, [[J Crew]])<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/27/business/media/newfronts-make-bids-for-big-marketing-dollars.html?_r=0 "NewFronts Make Bids for Big Marketing Dollars"] New York Times. April 2012.</ref> **YouTube fashion stars [[Elle and Blair Fowler]] performed a live style haul *[[Jonah Peretti]] (Founder & CEO, [[Buzzfeed]]) and Ron Faris (Head of Brand Marketing, Virgin Mobile) in a discussion about audience development *Live content pitches from [[Heidi Klum]], [[Anthony E. Zuiker]], David van Eyssen *Actress [[Rashida Jones]] launched her Twitter account live on-stage after a staged [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zBvmDjVvjSA “Digital Intervention”] by Bravo’s [[Andy Cohen (television personality)|Andy Cohen]], Mashable’s [[Pete Cashmore]], moderated by Krista Smith (Vanity Fair)<ref>[http://www.adweek.com/news/technology/big-names-bold-claims-digitas-newfront-139874 "Tom Hanks, Anthony Zuiker, Microsoft Kinect at the Digitas NewFront"] Adweek. April 2012.</ref>
====2013 ==== *Media theorist [[Doug Rushkoff]], Author of Present Shock: When Everything Happens Now <ref>[http://www.dmnews.com/rushkoff-put-down-the-botox-and-join-real-life/article/292081/ “Put Down the Botox and Join Real Life”] Direct Marketing News. May 2013.</ref> *[[Tina Brown]], Mark-Hans Richer (CMO, [[Harley Davidson]]), and Jules Daly (President, RSA), in a storymaking discussion led by transmedia storyteller Alison Norrington of storycentralDIGITAL *[[David Karp]] (Founder & CEO, [[Tumblr]]) *Adam Bain (President, Global Revenue, [[Twitter]]) and Peter Vesterbacka ([[Rovio Entertainment]], the creators behind the video game franchise [[Angry Birds]]), in conversation led by John McCarus (Digitas) *[[Arianna Huffington]]<ref>[http://www.adexchanger.com/agencies/digitas-and-huffpost-attempt-real-time-native-ads/ “Digitas and Huff Post Attempt ‘Real-Time’ Native Ads”] Ad Exchanger. May 2013.</ref> *[[Eric Hippeau]] (Partner, Lerer Ventures) *A "Brands as Software" discussion between Richelle Parham (CMO, [[eBay]]), Bob Kupbens (VP, Marketing & Digital Commerce, Delta), moderated by Jason Spero (Global Head of Performance Media, Google) *Blake Shaw (Data Scientist, [[Foursquare]]) *Amy Kavanaugh (Chief Public Affairs Officer, [[Taco Bell]]) & Juliet Corsinita (VP, Media and Brand Partnerships, Taco Bell) *[[Brian Wong]], Founder of [[Kiip]] *[[Steve Martin]] in a discussion with Joe Levy (Billboard)<ref>[http://www.streamingmedia.com/Articles/News/Online-Video-News/Digitas-NewFront-Extolls-the-Power-of-Now-Focuses-on-the-Message-89421.aspx “Digitas NewFront Extolls the Power of Now, Focuses on the Message”] Streaming Media. May 2013.</ref>
==== 2014 ==== * Expanded to Europe, held in the UK <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.digitaslbi.com/en-gb/solutions/newfront|title=DigitasLBi|website=www.digitaslbi.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-10-25}}</ref>
==== 2017 ==== * Expanded to Asia, held in Singapore <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedrum.com/news/2017/06/20/data-driven-points-view-tripadvisor-spotify-uber-and-digitaslbi-data|title=Data-driven points of view: Tripadvisor, Spotify, Uber and DigitasLBi on data|work=The Drum|access-date=2017-10-25|language=en}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
==Further reading== * Samardak, Kelly (June 4, 2009). [http://www.mediapost.com/publications/?fa=Articles.showArticle&art_aid=107344 “Just An Online Minute...You're Either Newfront Or You're Oldbehind] and [https://web.archive.org/web/20110916022826/http://www.mediapost.com/publications/?fa=Articles.showArticle&art_aid=107383 "Just An Online Minute... Green Beer And Faith Butter At The Newfronts"]. MediaPost. * Reagan, Gillian (May 25, 2009). [http://www.observer.com/2009/media/observers-guide-geekery-internet-week-new-york “The Observer’s Guide to Geekery at Internet Week New York”] – ''[[The New York Observer]]''. * Lombardi, Gian (June 9, 2008). [http://www.yume.com/blog/2008/06/09/digitas-newfront-event-in-nyc/ “Digitas’ NewFront Event in NYC”]. Take 2 Video Blog. * Shields, Mike (June 5, 2008). [http://www.mediaweek.com/mw/content_display/news/digital-downloads/broadband/e3i5f72d636331a44a75c8bbc713aa22899 ” 'Digital Newfront' Weighs Web Video Gains, Goals”]. ''[[Mediaweek]]''.
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.digitasnewfront.com/}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=June 2008}} [[Image:Displace me X.jpg|thumb|Promotional poster]]
'''Displace Me''' was a nationwide event hosted by the nonprofit [[Invisible Children Inc]]. on April 28, 2007. In 15 cities across the [[United States]], 68,000 individuals came together to raise awareness about the situation of the [[Displaced persons camp|displacement camps]] in northern [[Uganda]].
The event had three main goals: #To educate participants about displacement camps in the North by simulating, as best as possible, the experience of living in an IDP camp. #To create greater national and international attention of the humanitarian crises in northern Uganda. #To garner the political attention needed to see a peaceful resolution to the [[Lord's Resistance Army insurgency]], primarily through the appointment of one senior level U.S. diplomat.
==The event== Displace Me was created to be an experiential event. To encourage the simulation, participants were asked to bring the following: *Enough cardboard to build something the size of a small tent. *A sleeping bag. *A 1.5-liter bottle of water (with an airtight seal—to be collected upon entry). *A box of saltine crackers (with sealed packaging—to be collected upon entry). *A current photo of you wearing a white T-shirt with a red X.
With 15 locations across the United States, participants had to travel long distances to reach their “camps.” The traveling aspect was reflective of the displaced individuals in northern Uganda who were given 48 hours to leave their homes and relocate to displaced camps throughout the region. Once Displace Me participants arrived at their camps, they built “huts” out of cardboard boxes. Throughout the remainder of the night, participants were rationed food and water and heard, via video, personal testimonies from those living in the IDP camps in the North.
Other aspects of the event included a speech at every city from an individual personally connected with the conflict. Speakers included the Gulu District Chairman [[Norbert Mao]], Invisible Children’s Ugandan Country Director '''Jolly Okot''', and the Senior Adviser to the International Crisis Group [[John Prendergast (activist)|John Prendergast]], among others. First Lady [[Laura Bush]] also directly addressed the Displace Me participants via a prerecorded speech shown on video. Participants concluded the night by writing letters to their government leaders and the President of Uganda, calling friends and family who were not aware of the conflict, as well as holding 21 minutes of silence for the 21 years of war.
During the night participants also helped film a video that was to be shown to members of the [[United States Senate]]. Participants in each city held up giant banners with their city's name and one to two phrases from the below statement.
==See also== *[[Global Night Commute]] *[[Schools for Schools]] *''[[Invisible Children|Invisible Children: Rough Cut]]'' *''[[Kony 2012]]''
==External links== *{{official website|https://web.archive.org/web/20080610063400/http://www.invisiblechildren.com/displaceMe}}
{{Invisible Children Inc.}} [[Category:2007 protests]] [[Category:Invisible Children]] [[Category:Organized events]]
